Students will be expected to assume a much increased responsibility for student learning, classroom management, and evaluation. Students are expected to apprise themselves of Field Experience dates, duration and responsibilities as outlined on the Internships and Student Affairs website at www.mcgill.ca/isa.

programCourse.name: Fourth Field Experience (TESL)
programCourse.description: Student Teaching : Supervised student teaching in a school. Students will be expected to assume a much increased responsibility for student learning, classroom management, and evaluation. Students are expected to apprise themselves of Field Experience dates, duration and responsibilities as outlined on the Internships and Student Affairs website at www.mcgill.ca/isa.

programCourse.name: Fourth Field Experience (Physical Education)
programCourse.description: Student Teaching : A minimum of 35 days of supervised teaching Physical Education in a school.

programCourse.name: Introduction to Physical and Health Education in Quebec
Health Education
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : A study of the teacher's role in the total school health program at both elementary and high school levels; current issues in contemporary health education.

programCourse.name: Biomechanics of Human Movement
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Analysis of fundamental human movement and the kinematic concepts which underlie each: Stability, agility, walking, running, jumping, throwing, absorbing forces, striking, kicking, spinning, twisting, aquatics and work positions.

programCourse.name: Biomechanics and Motor Learning
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Nature and mechanical function of human movement in sport, dance, physical recreation and adapted movement activities.

programCourse.name: EDKP
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Acquisition of skills and techniques in aquatics.

programCourse.name: Track and Field
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Using track and field to address a variety of progressions of learning that are included at all levels of, and in relation to, the Quebec Physical Education Curriculum. The Sport Education model will be utilized to stress the transferability of the sport-specific skills needed to engage in track and field.

programCourse.name: Games 1: Elementary Physical Education
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Focus on Teaching Games For Understanding, in relation to the Quebec Physical Education Curriculum, which includes invasion games, target games, net and wall games, and striking and fielding games. Emphasis will be placed on fundamental movement through a variety of games and physical activities.

programCourse.name: Games 2: Secondary Physical Education
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Focus on Teaching Games For Understanding, in relation to the Quebec Physical Education Curriculum, to explore sport-specific skills, tactics, and strategies that are included across traditional sports and settings. The conceptual teaching of physical education will be emphasized.

programCourse.name: Health-Related Fitness
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Participation in activities surrounding the components of cardiovascular fitness, strength, and flexibility. Exposure to a variety of fitness assessments as well as how these assessments can be used to connect to the Quebec Physical Education Curriculum’s student plans of action in regards to overall health and well-being.

programCourse.name: Non-Traditional Physical Activities
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Martial arts, meditation,stress releasing and other related activities will be introduced to incorporate these activities into future physical education and health programs. The Quebec Physical Education Curriculum will be utilized.

programCourse.name: Introductory Principles in Applied Kinesiology
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : A combination of lectures and practical demonstrations in applied kinesiology.

programCourse.name: Movement Education
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : A Laban theme-based approach will be incorporated through dance, gymnastics, circus and parkour. Basic movement patterns of balance, landings, rotations, and locomotion will be taught. Developmental lesson planning and safety will be incorporated throughout the course.

programCourse.name: Motor Development
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Changes apparent in motor behaviour from conception to old age. Two perspectives are emphasized: 1) contemporary and historical theories of human development, 2) development of motor behaviour and influences of physical growth, sensori-perceptual development, information processing and socio-cultural factors.

programCourse.name: Nutrition and Wellness
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : This course will examine the role of carbohydrates, fats, proteins, vitamins, minerals and water in a balanced diet. Students will be introduced to the affects of nutrition on exercise, sport performance and wellness. The validity of claims concerning nutrient supplements will be studied.

programCourse.name: Anatomy and Physiology
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Basic foundations of structural, neuromuscular and visceral anatomy extending to the basic elements of the neuromuscular, circulatory and respiratory systems with emphasis on applications in instructional and coaching settings.

programCourse.name: Special Topics 02
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Content will vary from year to year and will be announced prior to registration. The course will be given by a single instructor or by a group, as the occasion warrants.

programCourse.name: Kinesiology Internship 1
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : A skills-based practical experience in kinesiology.

programCourse.name: Kinesiology Clinic Internship 1
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : A skills-based practical experience in the on-campus Kinesiology Clinic.

programCourse.name: Evaluation in Physical Education
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Measurement and evaluation techniques designed to assess progress in physical education settings.

programCourse.name: Physical Activity and Public Health
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Introduction to literature on the role of physical activity and general health and well-being. Examination of exercise adherence issues, exercise prescription, and the economic impact of physical fitness programs in the workplace. Epidemiologic literature. Concepts of health promotion and public health.

programCourse.name: Physical Education Methods
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : This course is a prerequisite for all field experience and practice.) Designed to prepare students for a teaching/leadership role in physical education. They will examine teaching/leadership effectiveness as it relates to organization and observation techniques, planning, instruction and evaluation of physical activity.

programCourse.name: Physical Fitness Evaluation Methods
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Provides hands-on skills and training required to work as a kinesiologist. Focus is placed on risk assessment, fitness evaluation methods, collection and interpretation of client data and individualized physical fitness prescription. Lecture and practical lab hours included.

programCourse.name: Physiology in Sport and Exercise
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Examination of the responses of the human body during and following acute and chronic exercise with practical applications for a school setting.

programCourse.name: Historical Perspectives
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : A historical survey of the form and function of organized sport and physical activity.

programCourse.name: Exercise Physiology
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Examination of the physiological responses of the neuromuscular, metabolic, endocrine, and circulatory and respiratory systems to acute and chronic exercise.

programCourse.name: Adapted Physical Activity
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Assessment, instruction and evaluation in physical activity for special populations. Emphasis on inclusion of people labelled intellectually disabled, learning disabled, physically awkward, autistic, visually or hearing impaired and physically disabled. Weekly lectures plus practical teaching lab.

programCourse.name: Kinesiology Internship 2
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : A skills-based practical experience in kinesiology.

programCourse.name: Kinesiology Clinic Internship 2
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : A skills-based practical experience in the on-campus Kinesiology Clinic.
programCourse.prerequisites: EDKP 250, EDKP 301 or EDKP 302, PHGY 209, PHGY 210;

programCourse.name: Sport in Society
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : An examination of the cultural, social, political and economic factors that influence sport in society. Special attention to the effects of gender, financial constraints and political policies on involvement in physical activity and sports programs.

programCourse.name: Physical Education Pedagogy
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : This pedagogy course builds on physical education methods and field experiences. It focuses on the developing teacher, the establishment of the learning environment, and the implementation of the varied teaching strategies. Principles of research on teaching in physical education are translated into practical techniques for application in the field.

programCourse.name: Research Methods
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : How to conduct and understand research in physical activity, including a complete overview of the research process, statistical and measurement concepts in research, the various types of research including both quantitative and qualitative aspects, as well as ways of presenting research.

programCourse.name: Ergonomics
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : An examination of ergonomic issues including: injury mechanisms, evaluation and assessment techniques, occupational health and safety legislation, and ergonomic interventions.

programCourse.name: Exercise Metabolism
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : The biochemical structure and regulation of major biochemical pathways related to exercise. Examine the hormonal regulation of lipid, carbohydrate and protein metabolism during short and prolonged exercise as well as the influence of physical training. Examine gender-related differences and exercise metabolism.

programCourse.name: Physical Activity and Ageing
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Review of ageing-related changes in circulatory, respiratory, neuromuscular, hormonal, metabolic and immune systems as they relate to functional limitations and the physiological responses to acute and chronic exercise. Examination of the role of exercise in mitigating ageing response.

programCourse.name: Motor Control
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Basic concepts of neuromuscular control of human limb movement. Neural circuitry of sensorimotor networks in the spinal cord and brains. Principles of feedback and feedforward control of body mechanics. Neural mechanisms of motor learning and adaptation.
programCourse.prerequisites: EDKP 206, PHGY 201 or PHGY 209, PHGY 202 or PHGY 210, EDKP 261;

programCourse.name: Exercise and Health Psychology
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : The psychological aspects of health and participation in exercise and physical activity. The application of psychological knowledge and methodology within exercise and health. Theory and evidence on selected topics in this area of study.

programCourse.name: Neuromuscular and Inflammatory Pathophysiology
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Review of the physiological bases of selected disorders of the immune, renal, neurological and muscular-skeletal systems and an examination of the particularities of exercise responses and the effects of exercise conditioning in these populations. A special emphasis on the scientific bases for exercise prescription.

programCourse.name: Advanced Principles in Applied Kinesiology
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : To introduce the elements of a periodization plan.

programCourse.name: Personal Trainer Practicum
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : A practical work-study experience with a focus on instruction and experience in personal training.

programCourse.name: Research Practicum in Kinesiology
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Supervised research practicum in kinesiology.

programCourse.name: Honours Research Practicum
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Supervised directed study and research leading to the development of a formal undergraduate thesis proposal.

programCourse.name: Cardiopulmonary Exercise Pathophysiology
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : The physiological bases of selected cardiovascular, respiratory and metabolic disorders and an examination of the particularities of exercise responses and the effects of exercise conditioning in these populations. A special emphasis on the scientific bases for exercise prescription.

programCourse.name: Physical Education Curriculum Development
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Analysis of important philosophies, principles, and personal, educational, and societal issues that influence current physical and health education curricula with particular emphasis on the Québec curriculum for Physical Education and Health.

programCourse.name: Scientific Principles of Training
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Application of physiological and kinesiological principles in the selection and evaluation of athletic and physical fitness programs. Specific topics studied will include aerobic and anaerobic training, interval training, circuit training, weight training for muscular strength and endurance, flexibility, motor ability, obesity and energy balance.

programCourse.name: Sport Psychology
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : The psychological aspects of participation in sport and physical activity relative to performance enhancement.

programCourse.name: Undergraduate Honours Research Project
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Supervised preparation of an Honours research project under the direction of a faculty member.

programCourse.name: EDKP
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Supervised preparation of an Honours research project under the direction of a faculty member.

programCourse.name: EDKP
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : See EDKP 499D1 for course description.

programCourse.name: Applied Exercise Psychology
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : This course examines common theories and interventions used to understand and promote physical activity by (a) reviewing, discussing, and critically evaluating theories of health behaviour change, and (b) learning and applying physical activity counselling strategies.

programCourse.name: Advanced Biomechanics Theory
programCourse.description: Kinesiology&Physical Education : Examination of biomechanical applications in various contexts such as clinical, ergonomic, sport, aging, comparative, robotics.

programCourse.name: Facilitating Relationships
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Counselling) : Components of effective interpersonal relationships and how to facilitate them in a variety of contexts.

programCourse.name: Group Processes and Diversity
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Counselling) : Theories and exploration of group development and processes, including an examination of research, and how intersectional and universal design have implications for group work.

programCourse.name: Intersectional Relationships and Sexualities
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Counselling) : Situated in sexuality studies and education this course explores intra and interpersonal relationships through examining the intersections of sexuality with a diversity of identities, expressions and communities. The course addresses the ways in which current and emerging technologies influence and inform understandings of sexuality and the resulting effect on how people negotiate sexual relationships.

programCourse.name: Communication and Critical Conflict Resolution
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Counselling) : Applying a social justice framework this course will give students the opportunity to develop the critical communication skills necessary when addressing difficult dialogues and conflict.

programCourse.name: Crisis Intervention Processes
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Counselling) : General overview of symptoms for different crises and how different professionals can intervene and refer, including ethical and professional issues.

programCourse.name: Advocacy, Outreach and Leadership
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Counselling) : Exploration of the roles of advocacy, outreach and leadership in developing inclusive and accessible environments, including the complex interactions between individuals and the diversity of systems in which they live.

programCourse.name: End of Life Care
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Counselling) : Exploration of how end of life care is delivered and interpreted across divergent socio-cultural contexts by applying an intersectional framework.

programCourse.name: Social Responsibility and Relationships in Digital Age
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Counselling) : The complex way in which living in a digital age affects social relationships and its influences across generations in everyday lives.

programCourse.name: Career as a Lifelong Process
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Counselling) : Career exploration for teachers, students and others across the lifespan. Creating inclusive and safe working environments, valuing diversity, career awareness, career growth and development, career decision-making, transferable skills, and school-to-work transitions for all.

programCourse.name: Educational Psychology
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Psychology) : Selected theories, models, and concepts relevant to planning and reflecting upon educational practice and improvement. Overview of development, learning, thinking, motivation, individual difference, etc. In relation to applications in classroom teaching and learning, the complementary role of counsellors and psychologists, educational computing and technology. The Youth Protection Act.

programCourse.name: Measurement and Evaluation
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Psychology) : The purposes of examinations. Causes of complaints about examinations. Equalizing means and dispersions in distribution of marks. Standardized scores. The percentile system. Essay and objective-type examinations. Taxonomies of educational objectives. Validity and reliability: item analysis.

programCourse.name: Instructional Psychology
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Psychology) : Psychological processes in instruction and learning, assessment, and curriculum design, based on theories of cognition, motivation, and the social context of instruction.
programCourse.prerequisites: An introductory course in psychology or EDPE 300;

programCourse.name: Cognition and Education
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Psychology) : Cognition and learning in educational domains and contexts. Contributions of cognitive science to issues in education including domain-specific and general knowledge and expertise, situated cognition and learning, cognitive apprenticeship, and uses of computers and networks as cognitive tools in educational settings.
programCourse.prerequisites: PSYC 213 or permission of the instructor;

programCourse.name: Introductory Statistics
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Psychology) : This online course provides an introduction to the fundamentals of descriptive and inferential statistics. Topics in descriptive statistics include introduction to statistics, measures of central tendency, variability and correlation. Topics in inferential statistics concentrate on basic procedures in between-group hypothesis testing using dependent and independent t-tests and within-group hypothesis testing using correlation.

programCourse.name: Adolescence and Education
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Psychology) : Development of personality and social behaviour in adolescence. Problems relating to self-concept, academic achievement, relationships with others, and development of values in a changing culture. Some attention to current criticisms of the school as an agency involved in adolescent development.

programCourse.name: Theories of Human Development
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Psychology) : Life course developmental theories to form a foundation for policy and for empirical and applied work with diverse groups, including disability and other equity-seeking groups.

programCourse.name: Gender Identity Development
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Psychology) : Theoretical models and empirical findings relevant to the development of gender identity. Special attention is given to the influence of peers in school settings. Psychological, physiological, parental, peer and cultural influences on gender identity.

programCourse.name: Instructional Design
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Psychology) : This course draws on the fields of learning theory, developmental psychology, and measurement to focus on the tasks of constructing instructional materials. Areas to be considered include behaviour analysis, concept formation, and test construction.

programCourse.name: Socio-Cultural Foundations of Learning Sciences
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Psychology) : Examination of foundational theories of the Learning Sciences including contributions by social constructivist theories. Implications of theory on methodologies for the Learning Sciences in general, and for educational and instructional contexts in particular.

programCourse.name: Statistics for Practitioners
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Psychology) : Understanding and interpreting basic statistical procedures used in basic and applied research, including graphs, measures of central tendency and variability, hypothesis testing, and correlations, t-tests, and basic ANOVA designs.

programCourse.name: Seminar in Special Topics 1
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Psychology) : The content of the seminar will vary from year to year and will be announced prior to registration. The seminar may be given by a single instructor or by a group, as the occasion warrants.

programCourse.name: Diverse Learners
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Inclusive) : Inclusion debates; review of the evolution of the history of inclusive education; models of development ( eco-systemic models); characteristics, teaching practices; teachers' roles in inclusive classrooms. Overview of characteristics, causes, needs, and teaching strategies for diverse and exceptional students, teaching and learning for differences in intellectual, emotional, behavioural, sensory, physical and learning domains found in effective inclusive classrooms. Working with families.

programCourse.name: Instruction in Inclusive Schools
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Inclusive) : Developing, planning, implementing and evaluating effective learning programs for diverse learners, and consideration of their more general applicability. Adapting curriculum and instruction for learners with varying abilities, learning styles, and needs. Collaboration with students, families, and other educators (or stakeholders) in the instructional process. Application of adaptations at the classroom and school level for all students in inclusive schools.

programCourse.name: Assessment for Instruction
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Inclusive) : Assessing student strengths, problems and needs; functions and use of different types of student assessment (traditional and alternative assessments); assessing the classroom environment; issues in assessment. Application component: application of assessment process with exceptional students, and use of results for planning and adapting instruction.

programCourse.name: Managing the Inclusive Classroom
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Inclusive) : Comprehensive approach to classroom management, including management of student learning and behavior, classroom environment, material and human resources, and teacher growth. Focus on research-based practices, including behavioral approaches, for effectively managing a classroom with diversity of students. Application component: application of classroom management principles in the field.

programCourse.name: Students with Behaviour Difficulties
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Inclusive) : Theoretical approaches and specific teaching methods appropriate to the needs of students with emotional or behaviour problems, including students with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Multimodal team intervention approaches are emphasized. Application component: application of teaching methods with students experiencing behaviour difficulties.

programCourse.name: Students with Learning Difficulties
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Inclusive) : Commonalities and differences between students with specific learning disabilities, and related teaching approaches. Emphasis on methods, materials, and technology for teaching academic content as well as social skills. Application component: modifying and teaching content areas to students experiencing learning difficulties.

programCourse.name: Supporting Students' Strengths and Talents
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Inclusive) : The psychology and practice of supporting the strengths and talents of all students across educational and community settings . Strength and talent-based programs and activities, assessments to discover student strengths and talents, classroom adaptations, application of strength and talent-based approaches to curriculum design.

programCourse.name: Creativity and its Cultivation
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Inclusive) : Recent research, theory, and educational practice concerning creativity, with special attention to creativity in students and educational settings.

programCourse.name: Field Work 1
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Inclusive) : Supervised experience in an approved relevant educational setting.

programCourse.name: Field Work 2
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Inclusive) : Supervised experience in an approved relevant educational setting.

programCourse.name: Family, School and Community
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Inclusive) : Focus on the examination of three important systems in a child’s life; namely family, school and community, as well as societal influences on student growth, development, and adjustment. Emphasis will be on evidence-based practices in collaborating with families and community organizations to form partnerships, classroom interventions and school-based initiatives to enhance well-being.

programCourse.name: Integrating Educational Technology in Classrooms
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Media) : The course is designed to help practicing and future teachers integrate current and emerging technology in their daily teaching practices. It is a practical, hands-on course that is grounded in constructivist learning theory. The participants will learn by engaging in authentic tasks in a project-based learning environment.

programCourse.name: Creating and Using Media for Learning
programCourse.description: Ed Psych & Couns (Media) : Creating and using media for learning. The course reviews audio-visual education (text, visuals, audio, video, and augmented reality), media and information literacy for K-11, higher education, and society, and how data are represented and used in education and research in different disciplines. The rationale and underlying principles for the design, production and effective use of media are emphasized.

programCourse.name: EDSL
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : How to observe in second language classrooms. Students will be introduced to ways of observing instructional practices and procedures and will begin to reflect on various interactional patterns between teachers and students as observed in the First Year Field Experience. Professional portfolios and professional competencies will be addressed.

programCourse.name: Communication in Education for TESL in Quebec
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Designed to develop academic and professional communication in education, both oral and written. Tailored to the needs of future ESL teachers in Quebec. Exposure to different professional and social situations via role playing, problem-solving, and various oral and written interactions in French and/or English as appropriate.

programCourse.name: EDSL
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : The course aims to develop basic practices in planning and teaching in ESL classrooms at the elementary and secondary levels, including reflective analysis. Professional portfolios and professional competencies will be addressed.

programCourse.name: Foundations of L2 Education
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : This introduction to the field of second language education provides an overview of the supporting disciplines (e.g., linguistics, psychology, sociology and education) and includes historical and analytical perspectives on the development of L2 teaching through an examination of approaches to L2 instruction and specific teaching methods.

programCourse.name: Étude de la langue
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Notions de base pour l'enseignement des composantes linguistique (lexique, morphologie, syntaxe et sémantique) et discursive (de la phrase aux types de textes et de discours); apprentissage de la grammaire nouvelle; composante langue des programmes d'études.

programCourse.name: Sociolinguistics and L2 Education
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : This course introduces students to various social aspects of language, language use, and language learning by examining second language education from three interrelated perspectives: sociolinguistics, discourse, and culture. Issues range from language variation and social attitudes to conversational analysis and cross-cultural communication.

programCourse.name: L2 Learning: Classroom Settings
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : This course provides an introduction to theory and research in second language acquisition (SLA). It is designed to help students understand the processes, developmental patterns and factors contributing to SLA so that the students will be prepared to evaluate and develop teaching procedures in light of this understanding.

programCourse.name: Pedagogical Grammar
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : The course focuses on how the English language works as a system, examining it from the levels of phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and discourse. These aspects will be considered in relation to second language teaching and learning.

programCourse.name: Third Year Professional Seminar
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Classroom processes such as teaching and learning strategies, lesson planning and implementation, classroom organization and management, and developing a reflective teaching and learning practice. Competencies and working professional portfolios will be addressed.
programCourse.prerequisites: EDSL 255 or EDSL 255D1/D2, and EDFE 255 or EDFE 255D1/D2, EDSL 305, EDSL 330, EDSL 334, EDSL 447;

programCourse.name: Literacy 1:Teaching Reading in ESL
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Examines current literacy theory and practice, focusing on the teaching of reading skills for the comprehension and appreciation of texts in various genres, formats and functions, in ESL for elementary and secondary level students. Top-down and bottom-up reading processes; cultural and general background knowledge; knowledge of language including grammar and vocabulary are addressed.

programCourse.name: Literacy 2: Teaching Writing in ESL
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Examines current literacy theory and practice, focusing on the teaching of writing skills for the production of texts in various genres, formats and functions, in ESL for elementary and secondary level students. Based on an understanding of writing as a process, key areas include: the adaptation and development of appropriate writing activities; feedback and revision; theme- and literature-based activities; and building upon reading and oral activities.

programCourse.name: Teaching Oral Skills in ESL
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Application of the English sound system to practical ESL teaching situations, planning and integrating pronunciation (as well as other oral skills, such as fluency) into activities and projects, developing materials, and assessing progress.

programCourse.name: Littératie et littérature jeunesse en FLS
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Développement de la littératie en langue seconde; les stratégies d'enseignement et d'apprentissage de la lecture et de l'écriture; l'exploration et l'utilisation de la littérature enfantine et de jeunesse propre à la francophonie dans divers contextes scolaires.

programCourse.name: Enseignement du FLS-immersion
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Ce cours examine divers cheminements retrouvés en contexte immersif ainsi que diverses approches pédagogiques propices à l'enseignement du FLS par le biais de matières scolaires. Des recherches effectuées en contexte immersif seront également examinées par rapport au développement langagier des élèves en immersion.

programCourse.name: Essentials of English Grammar
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Analysis of English phrases, clauses and sentences up to discourse level in connected text. Emphasis on distinguishing between grammatical form, meaning, and function. Identification, analysis and correction of common errors made by ESL learners.

programCourse.name: Assessment in TESL
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : This course deals with the role of assessment in TESL. Students will explore the kinds of information needed to make educational decisions in second language courses, different techniques for collecting that information, and ways for interpreting it. Principles and methods for assessment with and without tests are discussed and practiced.

programCourse.name: Fourth Professional Seminar
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Professional competencies and final preparation of professional portfolios will be addressed. Focus is on development as a TESL professional, preparation for the workplace, and analysis, reflection, problem solving and support of actual teaching practice.

programCourse.name: Laboratoire d'enseignement en français langue seconde
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Entraînement à l'observation et à l'analyse de situations d'enseignement du français langue seconde au primaire. Pratiques d'habiletés en situation microenseignement. Vidéoscopie et entraînement à la pratique réfléchie.

programCourse.name: Methods in TESL 1
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Intermediate-level skills in planning and teaching appropriate lessons, activities, and projects for ESL learners in a variety of programs at the elementary and secondary school levels.

programCourse.name: Methods in TESL 2
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Advanced-level skills in planning appropriate lessons, activities, units and projects for ESL learners in a variety of programs at the elementary and secondary levels.

programCourse.name: Foundations and Issues in Second Language Education
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Introduction of second language (L2) education; an overview of contributing disciplines (e.g., linguistics, psychology, sociology and education). A history of theory and various methodological approaches to L2 teaching and learning is used to promote an understanding of current theory and practice.

programCourse.name: EDSL
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Successful completion of a recognized exam attesting to a level of French Language Proficiency deemed sufficient to teach French.

programCourse.name: Second Language Acquisition Applied to Classroom Contexts
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : An overview of theory and research in second language acquisition, including developmental patterns, factors affecting how second languages are learned, and relevance for teachers in terms of applications to the classroom context.

programCourse.name: Grammar in Teaching English as a Second Language
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Analysis of English grammar at phonological, morphological, syntactic, semantic, and discourse levels. Applications are made to second language teaching and learning, focusing on integrating grammar into communicative language approaches.

programCourse.name: Étude de la langue française pour enseignants
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Notions pour l'enseignement du français langue seconde. Composantes linguistique (lexique, morphologie, syntaxe et semantique) et discursive (de la phrase aux types de textes et de discours); apprentissage de la grammaire nouvelle; composante langue des programmes d'études. Les demandes de deuxième langue d'enseignement et d'apprentissage axées sur l'intégration de la structure du langage dans les approches communicatives langagières.

programCourse.name: Littératie et littérature de jeunesse en contexte immersif
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Ce cours vise à conscientiser l'étudiant aux stratégies d'enseignement et d'apprentissage de la lecture et de l'écriture propices au développement de la bilittératie en classes d'immersion. Il explore de façon approfondie, le rôle de la littérature enfantine et de jeunesse dans l'apprentissage du français langue seconde en contexte scolaire.

programCourse.name: Didactique du français en contexte immersif
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Ce cours vise à amener les étudiants à s'engager dans leur processus de formation en vue de mettre à jour et d’enrichir leur pratique professionnelle ayant trait aux contenus et approches propres au contexte immersif, et ce, tant au primaire qu’au secondaire.

programCourse.name: Fondements pédagogiques de l’immersion
programCourse.description: Education in Second Languages : Ce cours examine en profondeur divers cheminements retrouvés en contexte immersif ainsi que diverses approches pédagogiques propices à l'enseignement du FLS par le biais de matières scolaires. Des recherches effectuées en contexte immersif seront également examinées d’une façon critique, par rapport au développement langagier des élèves en immersion.

programCourse.name: Applications of Educational Psychology Across Classrooms
Philosophy of Education
programCourse.description: EDTL : An exploration of philosophical underpinnings of educational theories as they inform professional practice. Reflections on aims of education, knowledge and values, nature of schooling and curriculum, roles and responsibilities of professional educators. All addressed through the development of professional competencies.

programCourse.name: Critical Influences on Educational Praxis
programCourse.description: EDTL : Implications of intercultural/multicultural, global, environmental and social justice advances as these affect critical thinking and inform practice in the classroom. Addressed through the development of professional competencies.

programCourse.name: EDTL
programCourse.description: EDTL : Two hour exam designed to assess teacher candidates' competency in the language of instruction - MELS requirement for teacher certification in the Quebec school system. Students are permitted 4 attempts to pass this exam; it must be passed before commencing the First Internship (EDIN 601). Any student unsuccessful after 4 attempts must withdraw from the program.

programCourse.name: Perspectives on Knowledge in Mathematics and Science
programCourse.description: EDTL : A variety of perspectives on construction of knowledge in mathematics and science and how the products of scientific and mathematical practices are shaped by broader social, cultural, and political forces.
programCourse.prerequisites: Students must have completed, with a grade of C or higher, a minimum of 24 credits in Mathematics and/or Science courses;

mandatory: Students must have completed, with a grade of C or higher, a minimum of 24 credits in Mathematics and/or Science courses

programCourse.name: Teaching Science and Technology
programCourse.description: EDTL : This course will build prospective teachersâ•Ž pedagogical knowledge and practices to teach principles of engineering and technical design, analysis of technical objects, and problem-based learning approaches to solve developmentally appropriate problems. Application of scientific concepts to technological solutions will also be emphasized to effectively integrate science and technology education.
programCourse.prerequisites: EDES 335 Teaching Secondary Science for BEd. Students only.;

programCourse.name: Elective 2 Clerkship

programCourse.description: Elective : Four (4) week clinical rotations.

programCourse.name: Departmental Survey of English Literature 1
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A survey of English literature before 1750 for students registered in English programs.

programCourse.name: Departmental Survey of English Literature 2
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A survey of English literature after 1750 for students registered in English programs.

programCourse.name: Introduction to Shakespeare
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A study of a selection of plays, in their intellectual and theatrical context, with an emphasis on the interplay of text and performance.

programCourse.name: American Literature 1
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A study of the literary works of earlier American writers.

programCourse.name: American Literature 3
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A study of literary works which may be thematic or may deal with a special group of authors.

programCourse.name: Canadian Literature 2
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A chronological survey of Canadian literature, Part 2. A continuation of ENGL 228.

programCourse.name: Introduction to Theatre Studies
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : An introduction to dramatic literature, text analysis, textual and performance theory, and theatre history.

programCourse.name: The Art of Theatre
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : Understanding, appreciation, and critical perceptions of theatre focussing on readings and lectures on issues such as the elements of theatrical practice; artists and innovators of theatre throughout history; and the theatre's development as an art form and social phenomenon.

programCourse.name: Introduction to Performance
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : The focus of this course is on the actor as communicator, and on those things (material, physical, and textual) which are inescapably central to the theatrical performance.

programCourse.name: Introduction to Cultural Studies
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A survey of cultural studies, its history and subject matter, presenting key interpretive and analytic concepts, the aesthetic and political issues involved in the construction of sign systems, definitions of culture and cultural values conceptualized both as a way of life and as a set of actual practices and products.

programCourse.name: Introduction to Film Studies
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : An introduction to key concepts in film studies. Exemplary works from the history of film will be studied to introduce students to such topics as the aesthetics of film; sound's production of meaning; film as narrative; film and genre; period and national cinemas; film's role in culture.

programCourse.name: Introduction to Film as Art
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : An introduction to film aesthetics, with emphasis on narrative, style and genre throughout the history of cinema.

programCourse.name: Postcolonial and World Literatures in English
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A critical introduction to the field of postcolonial and world literature studies, drawing on a selection texts from South and East Asia, Africa, and the Caribbean.

programCourse.name: Special Topics of Literary Study
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : Special topics of literary study. Topic varies by year.

programCourse.name: Earlier 18th Century Novel
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : Study of the English novel to c. 1750.

programCourse.name: Renaissance English Literature 2
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A study of major non-dramatic works of the later Renaissance in England.

programCourse.name: English Renaissance Drama 1
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : An overview of some major authors and issues in English Renaissance Drama.

programCourse.name: Poetics
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : Discussion and application of basic critical tools for analysis of literature. Study of such features of poetry and prose fiction as prosody, diction, voice, tone, imagery, figurative language, point of view, narrative form, and character.

programCourse.name: Canadian Drama and Theatre
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : Dramatic forms and theatrical practices in Canada from beginnings to the present day.

programCourse.name: Shakespeare
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A study of the major works of Shakespeare.

programCourse.name: Milton
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A study of the works of Milton.

programCourse.name: Theory of English Studies 3
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : Cultural theory now.

programCourse.name: Theories of the Text
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A course focusing on textuality (as opposed to, say, intentionality and interpretation) and on how specific effects are made - how texts work and produce meaning, including rhetoric and form.

programCourse.name: 20th Century American Prose
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A study of 20th century American prose.

programCourse.name: 19th Century American Prose
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A study of some of the major prose writers of the 19th Century.

programCourse.name: Development of Canadian Poetry 1
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A survey of Canadian poetry in English from the 18th century to the end of the Second World War.

programCourse.name: English Novel: 19th Century 1
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A study of representative novelists of the earlier 19th century.

programCourse.name: Literature Romantic Period 1
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A survey of representative literature of the earlier Romantic period.

programCourse.name: Development of Canadian Poetry 2
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A survey of Canadian poetry in English from the end of the Second World War to the present.

programCourse.name: Victorian Poetry
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A study of the major Victorian poets.

programCourse.name: The 20th Century Novel 2
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A study of 20th century novels.

programCourse.name: Introduction to Old English
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : An introduction to grammar and basic vocabulary in Old English.

programCourse.name: Literature and Science 1
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A study of literature and science. Topic varies by year.

programCourse.name: Literature and Society
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : An examination of issues relating to literature and its social contexts, such as implications of gender, race, ethnicity.

programCourse.name: Materiality and Sociology of Text
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : Writing, printing, distribution, marketing, and placement within canon-making institutions; the influence of material forms of production and transmission on the creation and reception of literature, film, and theatre.

programCourse.name: Great Writings of Europe 1
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A study of selected texts that significantly enhance understanding of English literature.

programCourse.name: Great Writings of Europe 2
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A study of selected texts that significantly enhance understanding of English literature.

programCourse.name: The Poetics of Performance
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : This course, normally taken in tandem with ENGL 230, examines and tests theories of acting, directing, and design through scene work and practical exercises.

programCourse.name: Middle English
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A study of works in Middle English.

programCourse.name: The Poetics of the Image
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : This course examines contemporary debates about the aesthetic dimensions as well as social roles of pictorial, theatrical, cinematic, and other representations, the meanings, effects, and aesthetic significance of which depend on their having visually recognizable features.

programCourse.name: Literary Criticism
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : Principles of literary criticism.
programCourse.prerequisites: at least 3 credits of ENGL 200, ENGL 201, ENGL 202, ENGL 203 Pre-/Co-requisite: ENGL 311. Required for but not restricted to Literature Honours students;

programCourse.name: Studies in the History of Film 3
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : Developments in post-1958 cinema, from the European New Waves to contemporary global and independent cinemas.

programCourse.name: Costuming for the Theatre 1
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : Introduction to costume-making for the theatre, covering fabrics, textiles and costume decoration.

programCourse.name: Stage Scenery and Lighting 1
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : An introduction to the technical aspects of stage settings and theatrical lighting.

programCourse.name: Theatre History: The Long Eighteenth Century
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A survey of dramatic forms and genres and theatrical practices from the Restoration through the 18th century to the Romantic period.

programCourse.name: Theatre History: 19th to 21st Centuries
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : History of predominantly Western theatre practices from circa 1830 to the present.

programCourse.description: English (Arts) : Aspects of stage scenery and theatrical lighting.

programCourse.name: Film Movement or Period
programCourse.description: English (Arts) : Study of a significant movement or period in film history.

programCourse.description: English (Arts) : A study of the dramatic text as literature, and as a basis for theatre production. Emphasis on character and character development, on structure and motivational units, and on the visualization of the play in performance.

programCourse.description: English (Arts) : An introduction to the study of television and its distinctive aesthetic, generic, and discursive features.
